title: Would judgements against me, for lawyer fees and sanctions, be covered in a chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: My divorce started with me filing a TRO. At the final hearing, the judge found that my ex had busted the door frame and put holes in our walls, but did not grant the TRO stating we were both at fault. My ex continued to drag out our divorce and custody, so that a new judge took over our case. During our divorce hearing, splitting bills and such, the new judge ordered I pay his lawyer fees for the cost of the TRO, payable to his attorney. I was also ordered to by the DCSS judge to pay sanctions on a set aside motion I filed to reverse what my then lawyer agreed to without my consent. My ex brings home $15-20 thousand a month and I take home maybe $1400 and the support for our two kids $468 a month from him. I cannot afford the $20,000, let alone all my other bills, so I have to file a BK. Can I include those judgements?
answers: It depends. I need additional information. For example, are the attorney’s fees secured by a lien against your property? You mentioned you were ordered to pay sanctions related to a motion to set aside an order. What was the motion and order pertaining to? Child support? Spousal support?

In addition to the potential issues addressed by my colleagues, 11 USC section 523 does not allow the discharge of a debt made as "for wilful and malicious injury"... Having worked in the field of family law, bringing claims in family court based on specious facts is pretty common. The fact that the court awarded fees, as well as sanctions against you suggests that there was a lot more going on than you have revealed in your post. I see filing bankruptcy as an invitation to continue the free for all battle you have engaged in during your divorce. Any evidence you might present that does not appear to be legitimate may result in you being nailed to the cross. I hope I am wrong, but you need to understand that the courthouse is not a place to play "gotcha" over your failed marriage. Hope this perspective helps!

Domestic support obligations are usually not dischargeable in a Chapter 7 case (some may be in a Chapter 13 case). Apart from alimony, child support, and other obligations in the nature of support, which are nondischargeable under § 523(a)(5), any other divorce related claims, including
obligations arising from property division or settlement, owed “to a spouse, former spouse,
or child of the debtor that are not covered by § 523(a)(5),” are nondischargeable under § 523(a)(15) if they were “incurred by the debtor in the course of a divorce or separation or in connection with a separation agreement, divorce decree or other order of a court of record…."

So the answer likely is, "No."

Good information already provided by my colleagues. Suggest you talk with a bankruptcy attorney near you to confirm your options and how these debts would be treated should you file bankruptcy. Good Luck.
The judgements from the state court would have to be read before an accurate deterioration colluded be made. Understand that any debt can be challenged via an adversary proceeding
Just be aware that you cannot discharge any debts related to child support and attorney's fees related to that.
Yes, both should be dischargeable debts, yes.
